Modules¶

app (main module)¶

Main module - game initialisation and (pygame) flow

class app.App¶

pygame app

static on_cleanup()¶

Called after main game loop, any clean up actions

on_event(event)¶

Process a pygame event

Parameters:event (pygame.event.EventType) – the event to process
on_execute()¶

Main code - initialise, main game loop, clean up

on_init()¶

Initialisation, called before the main game loop

app.init_game(player_details)¶

Create players, table and holding area

Parameters:player_details (list(tuple(player name, AI/None))) – the players

buttons (clickable screen areas)¶

class buttons.Button(rectangle, action, player_order=None)¶

Defines an action to be executed when a mouse click happens inside a specific rectangle (relative to a player’s area, if specified)

clicked(mouse_position)¶

Was the mouse clicked within this button’s rectangle

Parameters:mouse_position (int x, int y) – The position of the mouse click
Returns:True if this button was clicked on
Return type:bool
embody()¶

Embody (draw) the button

scaled_rectangle¶

Slightly larger version of the button area. Used to draw a line around the game piece, to show it is a button

Returns:slightly larger version of self.rectangle
Return type:vector.Vector
class buttons.ButtonCollection¶

A list of buttons - which can respond to a mouse click by executing the action which corresponds with the mouse’s location

add(rectangle, action, text=None, player_order=None)¶

Add a button, as specified, to this collection

Parameters:
  • rectangle – The area which will respond to a mouse click
  • action – (subclass of AbstractAction) action to take when mouse is clicked
  • text – If specified, show this as an actual button, including the text
  • player_order (int) – If specified, show in the specified player corner
Returns:

the button (class Button) that this created
Return type:

Button/VisibleButton
process_mouse_click(mouse_position)¶
Process the action for any button in self.buttons with the mouse click
position inside the button’s rectangle
Parameters:mouse_position – The (x, y) coordinates of the mouse
class buttons.VisibleButton(rectangle, action, text, player_order)¶

A conventional button: rectangle with text

colour_count (how many chips of each type do we have)¶

class colour_count.ChipCost(colour_count=None, raw_colour_count=None)¶

A ColourCount subclass which can be shown on a card as its cost

class colour_count.ChipStacks(colour_count=None, raw_colour_count=None)¶

A ColourCount subclass which can be shown as a stack of chips in the supply

class colour_count.ColourCount(colour_count=None, raw_colour_count=None)¶
Maintain a count of chips by type (colour), or of cards by chip type
they ‘produce’
covers_cost(chip_cost)¶

Do the chips we’ve counted cover the cost specified. Yellow chips are used as wild cards

Parameters:chip_cost (ColourCount) – The cost to cover
Returns:True, if this covers the cost
Return type:bool
filter(remove_blanks=False)¶

Different way(s) to filter down the colour count

Parameters:remove_blanks (bool) – If True, remove any dict keys with 0 value
Returns:if remove_blanks, colour count for non-zero values, else original colour count
Return type:ColourCount
items()¶
Returns:list(key:value) of the colour count
class colour_count.PlayerCardStack(colour_count=None, raw_colour_count=None)¶

A ColourCount subclass representing the ‘reward’ (in chip count) given by a player’s cards

class colour_count.PlayerChipStack(colour_count=None, raw_colour_count=None)¶

A ColourCount subclass which can be shown as a stack of chips for a player

game (the game state)¶

class game.Game¶

Container for game state: components, buttons, players and mechanics

current_player¶
Returns:The active player
Return type:player.Player
embody()¶

Embody the game: draw the table top, the components and score, and create the buttons

init_game(players, buttons, components, mechanics)¶
Parameters:
  • players (list(player.Player)) – The 2, 3 or 4 players in the game
  • buttons (button.ButtonCollection) – The active buttons
  • components (game_component_database.ComponentDatabase) – All the game pieces in the game, including in the supply, the holding areas and the players’ areas
  • mechanics (game_mechanics.GameMechanics) – Calculates the valid moves, winner, score and other game mechanics
last_player¶

Is the current player the last player in this round

Returns:True if this is the last player
Return type:bool

game_actions (what happens when you press a button)¶

class game_actions.Cancel¶

Cancel the user’s action - return the pieces to their original location

static activate()¶

Return the pieces to where they came from

Returns:True, to trigger a screen redraw
class game_actions.Confirm¶

Confirm the user’s action

static activate()¶

Confirm the user’s action (selected pieces)

Returns:True, to trigger a screen redraw
class game_actions.ToDo(actions)¶

A list of things to do when a button gets pressed

activate()¶

Execute all the callables

Returns:True, to trigger a screen redraw

game_components (cards, chips and tile class definitions)¶

Classes for the game components: cards, chips and tiles. Components use a state machines to track where they are

class game_components.AbstractGameComponent¶

Abstract game component, sets up the state machine

move_back()¶

Move got cancelled, move the piece back

stash_state()¶

Remember the previous state, in case the current move gets cancelled

class game_components.Card(chip_cost, chip_type, points, row)¶

A card, which consists of:

  • chip cost: a set of chips to be paid when buying this card
  • reward chip: the discount which this card gives towards
    buying another card
  • points: victory points
class game_components.Chip(chip_type)¶

A single chip

class game_components.Tile(chip_cost, points)¶

A single nobles tile

settings¶

class settings.Config¶

Configuration - mostly the (relative) position of various screen elements

utils (utility functions)¶

class utils.SplitIntoIncludedAndExcluded(source, target)¶

Split up pieces in source and target:

  • self.included: both in source + target
  • self.excluded: in target but not in source
  • self.remaining: in source but not in target

Chips of the same colour are treated as the same piece. Unlike sets, the lists can contain multiple pieces of the same type. This is typically used to work out whether a player can take a piece, halfway through a turn, based on the list of available moves

utils.chip_type_for_colour_name(colour_name)¶

Convert a string (colour) to a ChipType

Parameters:colour_name (str) – colour, e.g. ‘red’
Returns:the ChipType for this colour
utils.pieces_match(a, b)¶

Are a and b either the same piece or the same colour of chip

Parameters:
  • a (game_components.AbstractGameComponent) – A game component
  • b (game_components.AbstractGameComponent) – Another game component
Returns:

True if A and B match

util_classes (utility classes)¶

Utility classes - (real/informal) enumerators

class util_classes.ChipType¶

The different types of chips/jewels

vector¶

class vector.Vector(x, y)¶

Simple 2 dimensional vector.

Supports +, -, *, ==

to_rectangle(size)¶

Convert this vector into a rectangle

Parameters:size – (width, height)
Returns:(x, y, width, height)
